Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to log my scheduled break at the call center. I glanced at the screen and saw it was Jamie, my best friend. I answered, and her voice was shaky—her car had broken down on the highway, it was late, and she was scared. She needed me to come get her right away. My heart twisted; I knew she’d do the same for me in a heartbeat. But as I looked at the clock, I realized my break was only fifteen minutes, and management had been strict lately. If I left my desk for longer, I’d get flagged, maybe even written up. The phone queue was already stacked, and my supervisor had just sent a reminder about sticking to our schedules. I could hear the desperation in Jamie’s voice, but I could also feel the weight of my job’s expectations pressing down on me. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, torn between being the friend Jamie needed and the employee my boss expected.
